text: USF / <extra_id_0> c-Myc <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> enhances , while <extra_id_0> Yin-Yang 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> suppresses , the promoter activity of <extra_id_0> CXCR4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , a coreceptor for HIV-1 entry .

Transcription factors <extra_id_0> USF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> USF2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> up-regulate gene expression ( i.e . , HIV-1 long terminal repeats ) via interaction with an E box on their target promoters , which is also a binding site for <extra_id_0> c-Myc <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

The <extra_id_0> c-Myc <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> oncoprotein is important in control of cellular proliferation and differentiation , while <extra_id_0> Yin-Yang 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> YY1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) has been shown to control the expression of a number of cellular and viral genes .
These two proteins physically interact with each other and mutually inhibit their respective biological functions .

In this study , we show that USF / <extra_id_0> c-Myc <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> up-regulates , while <extra_id_0> YY1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> down-regulates the promoter activity of <extra_id_0> CXCR4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , a coreceptor for T cell-tropic HIV-1 entry .
We have identified an E box around -260 and a <extra_id_0> YY1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binding site around -300 relative to the transcription start site .

Mutation of the E box abolished USF / <extra_id_0> c-Myc <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated up-regulation of <extra_id_0> CXCR4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter activity , and mutation of the <extra_id_0> YY1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binding site was associated with unresponsiveness to <extra_id_0> YY1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated inhibition .

These data suggest that USF / <extra_id_0> c-Myc <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> YY1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may play an important role in the HIV-1-replicative cycle , by modulating both the viral fusion / entry process and viral expression .
